occurrences.line_text: And had his staggering steede not shrunke for feare,
And staggering steps, to weet, what suddein stowre
Whose staggering steps thy steady hand doth lead,
And both as swift on foot, as chased Stags;
Staid not to waile his woefull funerall,
And long time with that saluage people staid,
But Satyrane with strokes him turning, staid,
Despaire breedes not (quoth he) where faith is staid.
He staid not lenger talke, but with fierce ire
She staid: with that he crauld out of his nest,
Whereby her course is stopt, and passage staid.
They here ariuing, staid a while without,
Shalbe by vision staid from his intent:
That seeke a Lady,---There he suddein staid,
Staid not to answer, scarcely did refraine,
But Triamond halfe wroth to see him staid,
Staid not, till it arriued in his side.
She staid not the vtmost end thereof to try,
With a sharpe showre of arrowes, which them staid,
The Prince staid not his aunswere to deuize,
The youthfull knight could not for ought be staide,
The other by him selfe staide other worke to doo.
When he him saw, for no demaunds he staide,
Staide not to succour her in that affright,
With th'other staide his Lady vp with steddy might.
He staide his hand according her desire,
Ne staied for his Damzell to inquire,
Did feele his pulse, she knew their staied still
Nor hedge, nor ditch, nor hill, nor dale she staies,
The red bloud trickling staind the way, as he did ride.
His ruffin raiment all was staind with blood,
Her truth had staind with treason so vnkind;
That all her goodly garments staind around,
The signe whereof yet stain'd his bloudy lips afore.
And balefull Oure, late staind with English blood:
Yet often stainde with bloud of many a band
Come see, where your false Lady doth her honour staine.
His burning eyen, whom bloudie strakes did staine,
The whiles with bloud they all the shore did staine,
Her natiue flesh, and staine her brothers bowre,
Sclaunder her guests doth staine:
So faire and tender, without staine or spot,
And with the liquor stained all the lond:
Which Greece and Asian riuers stained with their blood.
His honour staines with rancour and despight,
Which staines his snowy skin with hatefull hew:
Which did her lilly smock with staines of vermeil steepe.
My dearest Lord fell from high honours staire,
So goodly brought them to the lowest staire
For thy, she standeth on the highest staire
And both her hands fast bound vnto a stake,
For whose sole libertie I loue and life did stake.
Eftsoones he stood as still as any stake,
As she had got thereby, and gayned a great stake.
To let him loose, to saue their proper stakes;
Still as he went, he craftie stales did lay
Of such false blisse, as there is set for stales,
For seldome seene, a trotting Stalion get
And him behind, a wicked Hag did stalke,
The which with monstrous stalke behind him stept,
Whose root and stalke so bitter yet did tast,
Which though it on a lowly stalke doe bowre,
In thousand dreadful shapes doth mongst them stalke,
With sturdie steps came stalking in his sight,
And left to losse: his stalking steps are stayde
And stalking stately like a Crane, did stryde
Like carkases of beasts in butchers stall.
Bound like a beast appointed to the stall:
Like as a bullocke, that in bloudy stall
And shall see Stamford, though now homely hid,
Did softly swim away, ne euer stampe,
But most were stampt, and in their metall bare
He rau'd, he wept, he stampt, he lowd did cry,
Their steeds do stagger, and amazed stand,
Astonied both, stand sencelesse as a blocke,
I in defence of mine did likewise stand,
Till seeing by her side the Lyon stand,
Enough is, that thy foe doth vanquisht stand
The Gods stand gazing on, when she does ride
That well he could not touch, nor go, nor stand:
So oft as Slowth still in the mire did stand.
All stand amazed at so vncouth sight,
All stand astonied at her beautie bright,
And twixt him and his Lord did like a bulwarke stand.
Nor leaue his stand, vntill his Captaine bed.
Ne ought his sturdie strokes might stand afore,
Whiles some more bold, to measure him nigh stand,
And day and night her dores to all stand open wide.
Vpon that shore he spied Atin stand,
Which, those his cruell foes, that stand hereby,
But constant keepe the way, in which ye stand;
That in assurance it may neuer stand,
At sight whereof the people stand aghast:
That may emongst Alcides labours stand.
Proceeding to the midst, he still did stand,
Out of her secret stand, that day for to out weare.
Do greatly stand amaz'd at such vnwonted wonder.
Stand vp so long, and weapon vaine to weld,
Could stand on foot, now to renew the fight.
And they like men astonisht still did stand.
But none of them against his strokes could stand,
Gainst whom none able was to stand on ground;
Dismayd, that none of them in field durst stand,
And looking sterne, still ouer him did stand,
And turn'd his face away, as he did stand,
Right in the midst the Goddesse selfe did stand
He woxe, that lenger he note stand vpright,
There they beheld a mighty Gyant stand
But what on earth can alwayes happie stand?
But not for it this ods twixt vs doth stand,
Then for assuraunce to my doome to stand,
For equall right in equall things doth stand,
In which condition I right now did stand.
Be well aduiz'd, that he stand stedfast still:
Vppon two stubborne oakes, which stand so neare,
And on the ground the other fast did stand,
He either spoiles, if they against him stand,
Where he with boughes hath built his shady stand,
He boldly aunswerd him, he there did stand
Where she with her two sonnes did looking stand,
Declare it boldly Dame, and doe not stand in dout.
That made him stagger, and stand halfe agast
And that of him she mote assured stand,
He bad him stand, t'abide the bitter stoure
And of her grace did stand againe assured,
There when he saw those two so neare him stand,
But she that in the midst of them did stand,
But Calidore in th'entry close did stand,
When fairer faces were bid standen by:
He standes amazed, how he thence should fade.
She fastned hath her foot, which standes so hy,
For thy, she standeth on the highest staire
They him saluted standing far afore;
Before her standing she espied had,
But her two other sisters standing by,
And standing stoutly vp, his loftie crest
Whiles Guyon standing by, their vncouth strife does see.
Woxe sore affraid, and standing still a space,
But keepe his standing, and his shaftes eschew,
Vntill he came vnto a standing lake;
But standing high aloft, low lay thine eare,
The noble Mayd, still standing all this vewd,
The direfull distaffe standing in the mid,
About the Andvile standing euermore,
Standing with emptie hands all weaponlesse,
Standing alone on foot, in foule array:
And that same Knight and Saluage standing by,
Which when the Prince beheld, there standing by,
Was holpen vp, who him supported standing neare.
And standing on his tiptoes, to seeme tall,
And standing long astonished in spright,
Before her stands her knight, for whom she toyld so sore.
Amased stands, her selfe so mockt to see
Nor aid enuy to him, in need that stands,
Like as the sacred Oxe, that carelesse stands,
Her teme at her commaundement quiet stands,
Vnto a brasen pillour, by the which she stands.
The beast astonisht stands in middest of his smart.
And all the world in state vnmoued stands,
Proudly stands ouer, and a while doth pause,
As now in miserable state he stands;
There stands an Idole of great note and name,
Whilest still she stands as stonisht and forlorne:
Hard by a streight there stands a castle strong,
Or else abide the death, that hard before you stands.
Caught like the bird, which gazing still on others stands.
In those sad waues, which direfull deadly stanke,
Of muddie water, that like puddle stanke;
STANZAS IN 1590 REPLACED IN 1596 WITH OTHERS.
By this vpstarting from her swoune, she star'd
Her firie eyes with furious sparkes did stare,
How the rude Shepheards after him did stare,
It made her stagger oft, and stare with ghastly eye.
And stared sterne on all, that him beheld,
Lookt deadly dull, and stared as astound;
Stared full wide, and threw forth sparkes of fire,
And stared ghastly, some for inward shame,
Stared on her awhile, as one astound,
So stared he on her, and stood long while amazed.
And her faire locks vp stared stiffe on end,
And with long locks vp-standing, stifly stared
He gaz'd about, and stared horriblie,
And with sterne eye-browes stared at him oft,
The Marriner yet halfe amazed stares
Both staring fierce, and holding idely
Chattring their yron teeth, and staring wide
With staring countenance sterne, as one astownd,
Which when the Gyaunt spyde with staring eye,
Feare to his first amazment, staring wide
Thereat with staring eyes fixed askaunce,
Their staring eyes sparckling with feruent fire,
Staring with hollow eyes, and stiffe vpstanding heares.
Bent hollow beetle browes, sharpe staring eyes,
With vpstart haire, and staring eyes dismay,
All looking on, and like astonisht staring,
But stood long staring on him, mongst vncertaine feares.
Whose sences all were straight benumbd and starke.
Became starke blind, and all his senses daz'd,
His hart gan wexe as starke, as marble stone,
Not perceable with power of any starre:
And said, Faire knight, borne vnder happy starre,
His seuenfold teme behind the stedfast starre,
Mine, that did then shine as the Morning starre:
She said, Ah dearest Lord, what euill starre
As bright as doth the morning starre appeare
What if in euery other starre vnseene
Ah lucklesse babe, borne vnder cruell starre,
Death is for wretches borne vnder vnhappie starre.
That to a stedfast starre his course hath bent,
Whose glory shineth as the morning starre,
Whose noble deedes aboue the Northerne starre
As that faire Starre, the messenger of morne,
All as a blazing starre doth farre outcast
Ne chaunged was into a starre in sky:
Like to the Euening starre adorn'd with deawy ray.
Which in Star-read were wont haue best insight,
That molten starres do drop like weeping eyes;
With burning starres, and euerliuing fire,
Like twinckling starres, and all the skirt about
But saile withouten starres gainst tide and wind:
That now with thousand starres was decked fayre;
Amongst the lesser starres in euening cleare.
With glittering spangs, that did like starres appeare,
To tell the sands, or count the starres on hye,
For much more eath to tell the starres on hy,
As he, on whom the lucklesse starres did lowre,
And is vnto the starres an ornament,
To sparke out litle beames, like starres in foggie night.
With starrie beames about her shining bright,
Her loftie towres vnto the starry sphere,
Fraile harts, yet quenched not; like starry light
Her mantle, colour'd like the starry skyes,
There by th'vncertaine glimse of starry night,
That shynd, like twinkling stars, with stons most pretious rare.
Whose eyes like twinkling stars in euening cleare,
All in amaze he suddenly vp start
He lifted vp his hand, that backe againe did start.
And with sterne horrour backward gan to start:
Not suffering the least twinckling sleepe to start
Which from iust verdict will for nothing start,
On his aduenture, vowing not to start,
But that same knight would not once let him start,
He started vp, as seeming to mistrust,
He started vp, and did him selfe prepaire,
She weakely started, yet she nothing drad:
Tho vp he started, stird with shame extreme,
All vnawares he started vp anon,
And lightly started vp as one affrayd;
And started vp auenged for to be
Lightly he started vp out of that stound,
He started vp, there where on ground he lay,
He started vp, and snatching neare his syde
He lightly started vp like one aghast,
But to his starting steed, that swaru'd asyde,
Who therewith somewhat starting, vp gan looke,
And starting vp, streight for his armour sought:
Whereat the other starting vp dismayd,
Hastily starting vp, like men dismayde,
She starting vp, began to shrieke aloud,
That euen the wild beast shall dy in starued den.
Die is my dew: yet rew my wretched state
Crauing of you in pitty of my state,
High aboue all a cloth of State was spred,
So proud she shyned in her Princely state,
Why they were come, her royall state to see,
And gin to pittie her vnhappie state,
That blisse may not abide in state of mortall men.
That holds the world in his still chaunging state,
If in true ballance thou wilt weigh thy state:
And brought thee vp in ploughmans state to byde,
Proclaymed ioy and peace through all his state;
The large discourse of royall Princes state.
That oft they did lament his lucklesse state,
Eftsoones the Gard, which on his state did wait,
He was an Elfin borne of noble state,
Sith heauen thee deignes to hold in liuing state,
Which plunged had faire Ladie in so wretched state.
Such is the state of men: thus enter wee
Transformd her to a stone from stedfast virgins state.
To succour the weake state of sad afflicted Troy.
The priuate state, and make the life vnsweet:
To them, that liu'd therein in state forlorne;
To teach them how to vse their present state.
As well in state of peace, as puissaunce in warre.
Mongst whom he parted his imperiall state,
Too truely tryde in his extreamest state;
Whose countreis he redus'd to quiet state,
And ruled long with honorable state,
And naturall desire of countreys state,
So feeble is mans state, and life vnsound,
In which what euer in this worldly state
Lookt on them louely, still in stedfast state,
Let them returned be vnto their former state.
Exceeding much the state of meane degree,
the state of Artegall.
So tickle be the termes of mortall state,
And sendeth forth to liue in mortall state,
The state of life, out of the griesly shade.
But now in stedfast loue and happy state
Vnto her sonne, that lay in feeble state;
Or thou, Sir Peridure, her sorie state,
So drag'd him through the waues in scornefull state,
It yrkes me, leaue thee in this wofull state,
And makes ensample of mans wretched state,
Restore vnto her health, and former state;
Can wretched Lady, quit from wofull state,
Welds kingdomes causes, & affaires of state,
Amongst fraile men, that many a publike state
Long may you liue in health and happie state.
Till that to ripenesse of mans state they grew:
To ouerthrow my state and dignitie.
And him receiu'd againe to former fauours state.
Could shake the safe assuraunce of their state.
Yet was the younger stronger in his state
And all the world in state vnmoued stands,
And him restor'd to healthfull state againe:
So oft as I with state of present time,
The daungerous state, in which she stood, she feared
The bridegromes state, the brides most rich array,
Your misery, how fell ye in this state.
And all the wounded, and the weake in state,
As now in miserable state he stands;
Vnhappie Knight, vpon whose hopelesse state
Yet in the streightnesse of that captiue state,
And what he did, and in what state he stood,
That he is not the while in state to woo;
To hide thy state from being vnderstood?
Mongst many which maligne her happy state,
Had vtterly subuerted his vnrighteous state.
All ouer her a cloth of state was spred,
The cloth of state, and on their purpled wings
And mightie Conquerors, in royall state,
That goodly seem'd t'adorne her royall state,
That Castle was the strength of all that state,
Vntill that state by strength was pulled downe,
To which they had no right, nor any wrongfull state.
his state and present plight.
Ye may doe well in this her needfull state
So tickle is the state of earthly things,
This is the state of Keasars and of Kings.
To thinke of this ill state, in which she stood,
Such was the state of this most courteous knight
Or else remained in most wretched state,
Who from the high degree of happy state,
Would not bewray the state in which she stood.
How much (sayd he) more happie is the state,
And rageth sore in each degree and state;
A stately Pallace built of squared bricke,
Suddein vpriseth from her stately place
And placed vnder stately canapee,
Returnd to stately pallace of dame Pride;
Which in that stately building wont to dwell.
What stately building durst so high extend
And by her stately portance, borne of heauenly birth.
Those same with stately grace, and princely port
Was shot vp high, full of the stately tree,
A stately siege of soueraigne maiestye;
Thence she them brought into a stately Hall,
Vp to a stately Turret she them brought,
A stately Castle farre away she spyde,
And stately port of Castle Ioyeous,
Which stately manner when as they did see,
And like a stately Theatre it made,
There stood a stately Mount, on whose round top
And stately towres of Ilion whilome
Fayre Canacee vpon a stately stage
With stately steps, and fearelesse countenance,
On stately pillours, fram'd after the Doricke guize.
No not the stately Seuerne grudg'd at all,
But Auon marched in more stately path,
With stately port and proud magnificence,
Borne vppon stately pillours, all dispred
Where they a stately pallace did behold,
Taking them vp vnto her stately throne,
Her stately towres, and buildings sunny sheene;
He chaunst to spie a faire and stately place,
And stalking stately like a Crane, did stryde
In which all trees of honour stately stood,
Then Ruddoc and proud Stater, both allyes,
Inquireth of our states, and of our knightly deedes.
Of commen wealthes, of states, of pollicy,
And ciuill rule to kings and states imperiall.
When those gainst states and kingdomes do coniure,
Which tosseth states, and vnder foot doth tread
Ne durst behold: his stature did exceed
His portaunce terrible, and stature tall,
Of stature huge, and eke of courage bold,
A comely personage of stature tall,
She list discouer, and of goodly stature;
And eke in stature higher by a span,
Of stature huge, and horrible of hew,
Of stature huge and hideous he was,
Since I was ten yeares old, now growen to stature strong.
Him thus describ'd, to be of stature large,
Exceeding much the measure of mans stature,
And wholesome Statutes to her husband brought;
The Aspine good for staues, the Cypresse funerall.
Some rusty kniues, some staues in fire warmd.
Had power to staunch al wounds, that mortally did bleed.
And staunch the bleeding of her dreary wound.
And stopt the bleeding straight, ere he it staunched thought.
To stay the steppe, ere forced to retrate.
From turning backe, and forced her to stay:
Her soone he ouertooke, and bad to stay,
He would no longer stay him to aduize,
He left him lying so, ne would no lenger stay.
To wayle his woefull case she would not stay,
The mother of dread darknesse, and let stay
She hardly yet perswaded was to stay,
And in his hand a Iacobs staffe, to stay
Being in deed old Archimage, did stay
He hearkned, and did stay from further harmes,
From loftie steede, and bad the Ladie stay,
And all that might his angrie passage stay,
And by hard meanes enforcing her to stay,
For Gods deare loue, Sir knight, do me not stay;
But he him forst to stay, and tellen free
But th'other forst him stay, and comforted in feare.
And meetes a flood, that doth his passage stay,
Wont on a staffe his feeble steps to stay,
She would commaund the hastie Sunne to stay,
That nothing might his ready passage stay:
There eke my feeble barke a while may stay,
But he for nought would stay his passage right,
Vouchsafe to stay your steed for humble misers sake.
But his fierce foe his steede could stay vneath,
From foule intemperance he oft did stay,
Which to attend, a while their forward steps they stay.
Great fauour I thee graunt, for aunswere thus to stay.
Trompart forth stept, to stay the mortall chaunce,
O stay thy hand, for yonder is no game
But on a staffe her feeble steps did stay;
And therfore wisht me stay, till I more truth should fynd.
Sore chauffed at my stay in such a cace,
Ne thou for better hope, if thou his presence stay.
Appease his heat, or hastie passage stay;
The wind vnstable, and doth neuer stay.
And euer bad him stay, till time the tide renewd.
Both yeeld, to stay your deadly strife a space.
How without stop or stay he fiercely lept,
Below the earth, might suffred be to stay:
It seizd in his right side, and there the dint did stay.
Ne can I tell, ne can I stay to tell
Till ryper yeares he raught, and stronger stay:
And wearie waxe of his continuall stay.
Do serue their turnes: here I a while must stay,
With stedfast hand vpon his horse did stay,
Beene suncke, of whom no memorie did stay:
But th'other by his boate behind did stay.
Ne reckt of Ladies Loue, did stay behind,
Ne did she stay, till three on ground she layd,
With that the Prophet still awhile did stay,
Whereat she wondred much, but would not stay
Many meeke wordes, to stay and comfort her withall.
The Dwarfe him answerd, Sir, ill mote I stay
But could not stay; so fast she did foregoe,
Him boldly bad his passage there to stay,
Ne once to stay to rest, or breath at large,
On Tromparts steed her mounted without stay,
Ne long shall Satyrane behind you stay,
That weenes with watch and hard restraint to stay
But Satyrane forth stepping, did them stay
That in a cloud their light did long time stay,
Till Trompart ronning hastily, him did stay,
Here for to stay in safetie behind;
Ne banck nor bush could stay him, when he sped
So mighty be th'enchauntments, which the same do stay.
And on a broken reed he still did stay
The hurts whereof me now from battell stay,
To stay their hands, till he a while had spoken:
That nought mote stay the steele, till in his side
Yet not fit place he thought it there to stay,
Could stay, but to the tender flesh it went,
Were long to tell; therefore I here will stay
But swaru'd aside, and there againe did stay;
Would flit a litle forward, and then stay,
But they for nought their cruell hands would stay,
To stay his hand, and of a truce to treat
Whose manner was all passengers to stay,
Caught hold on me, and thought my steps to stay,
But Thame was stronger, and of better stay;
He bad him stay, and backe with him retire;
Whom he requir'd his forward hast to stay,
Loth was the Dwarfe, yet did he stay perforse,
And forst the burden of their prize to stay.
He nigh them drew to stay th'auengers forse,
Did stay a while their greedy bickerment,
To stay her stroks, and he himselfe would yield:
Ne would she stay, till he in place could come,
She saw it vaine to make there lenger stay,
Crying to them their cruell hands to stay,
Ne could the Souldan them from flying stay,
Did stay her cruell hand, ere she her raught,
Then let not that (said they) stay your intent;
They doe his anger calme, and cruell vengeance stay.
That nought the morrow next mote stay his fare.
There whilest they entring, th'one did th'other stay,
That it the Posterne did from closing stay:
Willd him to stay, and signe of truce did make:
And glad he was the slaughter so to stay,
